nodes.text: Decisions under uncertainty are best modelled by agents maximizing the time-average growth rate of wealth (ergodicity economics), and this time-optimality can be mapped to expected utility theory by identifying the ergodicity transformation with the utility function
Ergodicity economics (EE) models wealth as a stochastic process and proposes agents maximize the time-average growth rate of wealth (growth optimality) rather than ensemble expectation values
There exists a correspondence between EE and expected utility theory (EUT): the ergodicity transformation that renders growth rates ergodic can be identified as the utility function in EUT

If a utility function u(x) is invertible and twice differentiable, Ito calculus maps a Brownian motion in utility du = a_u dt + b_u dW to a unique stochastic differential equation for wealth dx with drift and diffusion determined by u

For EUT to be equivalent to time optimization, utility increments must be stationary and independent, implying utility follows an additive stochastic process which (assuming continuous paths) is a Brownian motion with drift

EE distinguishes between ensemble expectation values (relevant to pooled collectives) and time averages (mechanistically relevant to single agents), noting they are generally unequal for economic growth processes
EE broadens prior work by generalizing growth optimality beyond purely additive or multiplicative wealth dynamics to a wider class of wealth dynamics

When the time-average growth rate of wealth equals the expectation rate of change of u(x), maximizing expected utility with utility u(x) is equivalent to maximizing long-time wealth growth under the corresponding dynamics
Conversely, every invertible utility function defines a corresponding wealth dynamic for which expected-utility maximization is growth optimal (Theorem 1)
Because wealth dynamics are exogenous, the apparent utility function (and thus risk preferences) are predicted a priori from dynamics; if dynamics change, apparent preferences change

Application examples: linear utility u(x)=x corresponds to additive Brownian wealth; logarithmic utility u(x)=ln x corresponds to geometric Brownian motion; square-root u(x)=sqrt(x) yields mixed additive and multiplicative terms

Given a general Ito wealth SDE dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW, a consistent utility exists only if a_x and b_x satisfy au = a_x u' + (1/2) b_x^2 u'' and bu = b_x u' with constants au, bu, yielding differential conditions linking drift, diffusion and u

Requiring utility increments to be stationary and independent leads to u(t) being a Levy process; restricting to continuous paths yields Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW, ensuring the time-average growth rate exists and equals a_u
Experimental evidence with controllable wealth dynamics supports the prediction that dynamics strongly determine time-optimal behavior and apparent risk preferences
Utility functions should be treated as unbounded for the dynamic interpretation because bounded u(x) are noninvertible or produce mathematical pathologies (finite-time singularities or bounded time)
